descriptive.name: Introduction
descriptive.p: The Generic Incident Notification is a generalised, high level, yet encompassing report for the capture of information, in particular the circumstances surrounding an unplanned event or potential event that constitutes a Patient Safety Incident. These incidents can be reported by individuals involved in the process of care. The main purpose of using the GIN message is to gather snapshot information of the profile of a Patient Safety Incident (what, when, where, who) for the purpose of aggregation, analysis and learning, not specifically for the follow-up of individual reports.

A patient safety incident is defined as any unintended, expected or unexpected incident(s) that could have or did lead to harm for one or more patients receiving health care services. [Note: staff incidents are currently not reportable via this model.] Reports can cover actual patient safety incidents, including those caused by acts of omission, and prevented patient safety incidents (near misses). The reported data is then aggregated and analysed by health care agencies to identify areas of concern that warrant further investigation. The Generic Incident Notification not intended to support a detailed investigation of an incident (this will be covered by a future R-MIM - Patient Safety: Root causes and Underlying factors) nor necessarily to comply with regulatory reporting requirements.

Examples of incidents that would be reportable via the Patient Safety Generic Incident Notification are delays in access to care, medication errors, device failures, slip/trip/fall, patient misidentification, verbal/racial/sexual abuse directed towards a patient.

The Generic Incident Notification message model is described in the RMIM Walkthrough below; it is based around the concept of the report itself (the Incident Investigation), the Incident as a whole, and the Incident as it affects individual patient(s), and the Clinical Act(s) that were involved in the incident. All key acts apart from the Clinical Act(s) are in the mood of event, because they are describing a report or an incident that has occurred.

The "reporting" nature of this messaging is such that the dynamic model for this topic is simple. There is a sending system which informs and a receiving system that tracks that information. Trigger events are user-based, being activated when the user takes the decisison that a report, or a revised report, is complete; and the only state used is that of "complete". The main message interaction is therefore used to send an initial Patient Safety Generic Incident Notification, and a supplmentary message interaction is available to describe a revision of previously sent information which may be implemented if and when local business rules allow revision/update. Apart from system level acknowledgement, no other information flows occur.

p.emph: Differentiation from other Incident and Public Health Messaging Topics

descriptive.p: The Generic Incident Notification is distinct from the Individual Case Safety Report as it captures high-level information on a wide variety of patient focused incidents, which can include incidents affecting a group of patients. In contrast, the Individual Case Safety Report is designed to support regulatory reporting of adverse incidents associated with product safety. These products relate primarily to blood, medicines, including vaccines and devices.

The Generic Incident Notification also differs from Case or Outbreak Management. Case or Outbreak Management topics are intended to cover public health cases of reportable conditions e.g. infectious diseases.
Please note: The documentation for this topic has been written in UK English.

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to illustrate the completion of a Patient Safety Generic Incident Notification report

descriptive.name: Generic Incident Notification Gin Gin Create
descriptive.p: Baby Ben Blue was born prematurely in Good Health Hospital at a gestation of 28 weeks; he is now four weeks old, is in the Special Care Baby Unit and is doing well, but still requires ventilation due to poorly developed lungs.

On this particular day, Ben required a chest x-ray; this involved moving him to position the x-ray plate underneath him. To prevent the cardiac monitor and ventilator from alarming all the time while he is being re-positioned, the nurse "silenced" the alarms.
Once the x-ray was completed, the nurse and radiographer left the nursery to attend to another baby, but Baby Ben's cardiac monitor and ventilator alarms were not be re-set to sound.
During Baby Ben's repositioning at the end of the x-ray, a piece of the ventilator tubing had become disconnected; this resulted in Benbeing deprived of ventilatory support.

On returning to Baby Ben's room, the nurse noted that the cardiac monitor showed a heart rate of 40 and that Ben was cyanosed. She immediately identified the problem and reconnected the ventilator tubing. Baby Ben made continued to grow and develop, although it was found that he that he had suffered a small intracranial haemorrhage, which was thought to be due to the hypoxia suffered whilst the ventilator tubing had become disconnected.

The Charge Nurse for the SCBU fills in a Patient Safety Incident report form with details of Baby Ben Blue's incident, but without mentioning the patient's name, on the Risk Management System at Good Health Hospital. This system then automatically sends a report to the national Patient Safety Agency which collates and analyses all such reports and feeds back information to improve patient safety.

intref.refName: Generic Incident Notification Event Complete Notification

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to illustrate the revision of a previously completed Patient Safety Generic Incident Notification report

descriptive.name: Generic Incident Notification Revision
descriptive.p: A 70 year old man was admitted to hospital for a right nephrectomy. The patient signed a consent form giving the Urologist permission to perform such an operation. The next day, the patient's X-rays were reviewed and an entry was made in the Department diary for a left nephrectomy. This information was then re-entered on the Operating List.

The patient was admitted to theatre and a left nephrectomy was performed. After the patient came round, he was confused and lethargic, which prompted the Nurse to perform checks with the Urologist to ensure that his remaining kidney was functioning normally. It was during these checks that they discovered that the wrong kidney had been removed. The patient was immediately put on a dialysis machine to stabilise his condition. The next day the Nurse notified the Risk Manager that an incident had occurred.
The Risk Manager then reported the incident to the Patient Safety Centre stating poor communication and the mislabelling of X-Rays as proximate factors.

The Risk Manager at the aforementioned health care organisation decided upon subsequent consideration of the incident to change one of the proximate factors in the report to 'team factors'. He logged onto his local system within the time constraints set by local practice and changed a cached copy of the report. This revised incident notification was then submitted to the Patient Safety Centre where it was reconciled with the original record before the locally applied deadline.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Patient Safety Generic Incident Notification (GIN) RMIM is a high-level notification message, which captures information about any unintended, expected or unexpected incident(s) that could have or did lead to harm for one or more patients receiving health care services. As well as the reporting of incidents which affect an individual and cause harm, this definition includes:
1. Incidents that affect several patients
2. Incidents that have the potential to cause harm, but which do not adversely affect a patient
3. Incidents that are the result of "acts of omission"

As the GIN is a high-level notification message, only information that is readily accessible soon after an incident is captured in it. The information model assumes that there will be an electronic health record or similar to populate information about a patient's clinical condition using the clinical statement structure (A_CareStatementUniversal CMET). The model also assumes that message implementers would want to have a choice as to the level of identifiable information they wish to capture.

The GIN RMIM has four acts that form its main structural elements; these are the Investigation Event, the Incident Event, the Individual Patient Incident and the Supporting Clinical Statement that is a component of the Incident Event.

The Investigation Event is the entry class for the message, and describes that this is a report of a Patient Safety Incident, and it is from this class that the information about the Author of the report (and indeed the performer of any investigation that results in the report) is described. The Investigation Event links to the Incident Event class by means of a "Reason" relationship; without the Patient Safety Incident having occurred (or being a "near miss"), there would be no reason to have a report to notify an agency about it.

The Incident Event class describes some core information about the Patient Safety incident as a whole. This includes its type, when it occurred and any textual description of the incident. Associated with the Incident Event class are various classes to describe where the incident occurred, who were participants in it, and what form that participation took, how the incident was discovered, whether there were any factors that might be considered to have caused the incident (and if so, what if anything has been done to mitigate those things), any actions that were taken as a consequence of the incident as a whole, and whether the incident occurred in relation to a research study, such as a clinical trial. The Incident Event also has an association to describe if a group of patients, who are not identified separately, were involved in a patient safety incident.

The Assigned Entity CMET is used with the Participation into the Incident Event to describe any required information about the entity (person) who has been "assigned" to participate in (be employed in) the healthcare environment in which the whole Patient Safety Incident occurred, and thus who had a participation in the Patient Safety Incident in some way (including indirectly, e.g. as a witness). This is because the focus of the GIN is to collect information from healthcare staff about Patient Safety Incidents, so the role to be described is the staff's "assigned function" within the healthcare environment.

The Choice Box giving options about who performed the Discovery of the Patient Safety Incident is designed to capture only the type (role) of the person who made the discovery (a caregiver, a healthcare professional/member of staff, or a patient (who may be involved in the incident themselves, or an observer of it). This structure is not designed to describe any further detail about the "discoverer" since there is (currently) no requirement for this.

The Individual Patient Incident class that is linked to the Incident Event class by a component relationship, allows description of an incident as it relates to an individual patient, who may or may not be identified. Associated with the incident as it related to one or more individual patients, there are classes that describe more specifically who was responsible for this patient at the time of the incident, any actions that were taken to minimise the effect of the incident on this patient, any actions that were taken to help the patient recover from the incident, and to describe the effect(s) of the incident on this patient. In addition, for a "near miss" situation, there is the facility to describe any actions that were taken to "block" the patient from suffering harm from the incident. There are also structures to describe if the patient was the subject of a care pathway at the time of the incident, how the patient can be described in terms of particular age bandings used in safety incident analysis, and, by means of the Clinical Statement structure, to describe any relevant information about the patient's clinical condition at the time of the incident.

The fourth key structure in the GIN message is the Clinical Statement CMET that is associated with the Incident Event by means of a "component of" relationship. One or more iterations of the structure should be used to describe the clinical circumstances/detail of the patient safety incident, either in text or in structured form.

Optionality and Conformance The PSGIN RMIM as currently modelled for international DSTU status; as such, all the cardinalities are set to be as relaxed as possible and with conformance set as optional for all classes, relationships and attributes except those for which the structures would make no sense without the information.

div3.head: Individual Case Safety Report Release 2
div3.p: The Individual Case Safety Report (ICSR) Release 2 Draft Standard for Trial Use (DSTU) was approved by the Patient Safety Special Interest Group (PSSIG) and endorsed by the Regulated Clinical Research Information Management Technical Committee at the January 2007 Working Group Meeting. PSSIG submitted a formal request to the HL7 Board to add ICSR to the HL7 DSTU Comment Page June 12, 2007. Approval was received from the Board on June 21, 2007. The DSTU will be available for download from the HL7 DSTU webpage August 1, 2007 through July 1, 2008.

PSSIG will collaborate with the HL7 Implementation and Conformance Technical Committee to develop test plans, tools and other documentation to support ICSR DSTU testing. The US Food and Drug Administration will serve as an early adopter organization, and will coordinate with other parties interested in testing or further development of the standard. Interested parties should contact Ms. Lise Stevens, FDA at (301) 827-6085 or via email at Lise.Stevens@fda.hhs.gov.

The Patient Safety Special Interest Group would like to recognize the contributions of the following authors, editors, developers, and organizations without whom this document could not have been produced:

FDA Data Standards Council, AE Workgroup: The workgroup is comprised of program and IT representatives from all FDA Centers responsible for managing their respective adverse event reporting systems. These individuals contributed storyboards and over 90% of ICSR's content requirements for both ICSR Release 1 and ICSR Release 2. We especially acknowledge the work of the FDA Center for Devices and Radiological Health for their role in serving as the Agency early adopter and coordinating proof of concept testing for ICSR Release 1, which provided valuable feedback and requirements for improving the standard.

Mead Walker, Mead Walker Consulting: Mead has served as the primary modeling facilitator throughout the initial inception and evolution of the ICSR standard. He has demonstrated exceptional skill and commitment to deliver quality services and continues to support FDA's implementation of ICSR, and PSSIG goals to develop quality patient safety-related standards.

Anita Benson, DataScene: Anita served as the early modeling facilitator and champion for the ICSR. She has provided outstanding service, and has been instrumental in ensuring wider applicability and support for patient safety requirements, especially in the area of clinical trial AE reporting. Anita contributed the A_ReserachStudyEnrollment CMET, which is used in ICSR to capture relevant information concerning patient clinical trial enrollment.

Gloria Nunez, Oracle Corporation: Gloria, including other Oracle staff, has made significant contributions throughout the development of both releases of the ICSR standard. She has provided relevant, useful comments for changes and improvements during the balloting process which has resulted in delivery of a quality product. Oracle served as an early adopter/developer for ICSR Release 1.

Linda Fischetti and Freida Hall, US Department of Veterans Affairs: Linda and Freida (including other VA staff) have positively supported ICSR balloting, and have contributed comments and suggestions for improvements to the standard. Their review has been extremely valuable in ensuring that the ballot material was clear, accurate and relevant to healthcare provider organizations.

p.emph: We extend our special thanks to all those who take the time to review the ballot and submit comments.

div3.p: The Individual Case Safety Report (ICSR) Release 2 expands the scope of the 2005 Normative ICSR Release 1 standard to support other product categories such as food, food additives, dietary supplements, cosmetics, veterinary drug products, and combination products. Additional changes to the specification have been made to accommodate new requirements based upon the experience of pilot testing ICSR Release 1 to support electronic medical device reporting for the FDA Center for Devices and Radiological Health (CDRH), and support for human and animal reporting. A more detailed list of other improvements can be found in the Introduction section of the ICSR DSTU material.

p.emph: iv - Known Issues and Planned Changes

div3.p: PSSIG has not finalized logistics for posting material and will continue to coordinate with HL7 Headquarters and the Implementation and Conformance Technical Committee for guidance. The committee suggests that interested parties join the PSSIG list server, where documents and progress notes will be posted. The ICSR DSTU is available for download and comments can be posted to the HL7 DSTU Comment webpage: http://www.hl7.org/dstucomments/index.cfm

In addition to improvements introduced as a result of FDA DSTU testing, the committee is aware of ongoing work in the International Standards Organization (ISO) Technical Committee 215 concerning the collaboration between ISO, the European Committee on Standardization (CEN), the International Conference on Harmonisation (ICH) and HL7 to create an international adverse event reporting standard. This work is expected to support ICH requirements for revision to their E2B(M) Message Specification. The committee anticipates this work to be presented to HL7 sometime next year, and will incorporate new requirements into the next release of the standard.

The notification may include the report of an adverse reaction, of a product problem, or include information related to both adverse events and product problems.

intref.refName: Safetyreport Event Create Notification Icsr

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Individual Case Safety Report (ICSR) Refined Message Information Models (RMIMs) capture information about adverse events and product problems that are reported to public health, patient safety/quality improvement organizations or regulatory agencies. The ICSR message supports reporting from a variety of reporting sources such as consumers, hospitals, contract research organizations, clinicians or pharmaceutical product and medical device manufacturers. The HL7 ICSR Release 1 specification was most particularly oriented towards reporting of reactions to regulated drugs, therapeutic biologics, vaccines, and medical devices. In addition to the products supported in release 1, the ICSR Release 2 supports a wider variety of products including: a) veterinary products, b) food and food additives, c) dietary supplements and cosmetics, and d) combination products. ICSR Release 2 provides a minimal level of backward compatibility or harmonization with ICSR Release 1, by supporting concepts and attributes introduced in the original release, including international pharmacovigilence reporting requirements described in the International Conference on Harmonisation's (ICH) E2B M2 ICSR message transmission specification.

Implementation efforts by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for ICSR Release 1 to support medical device reporting revealed several limitations to the standard which required substantial changes to the ICSR Release 1 RMIMs. Some examples of these changes include streamlining the schema to support the reporting of adverse events and product problems within a single instance of the message, and the addition of a device observation class that is used to capture results from product evaluations performed by medical device manufacturers or reprocessors. Additionally, new requirements for other FDA regulated products required the creation of generalized product and product use models to capture concepts and attributes that can be used to support combination product reporting. The new R_Product RMIM introduced in ICSR Release 2 is based upon the Release 1 product-specific RMIMs for drugs (R_Drug) and devices (R_Device). These RMIMs are included in Release 2 to maintain a minimal level of backward compatibility between ICSR Release and 1 and Release 2; however, the ICSR Release 1 attributes for both drugs and devices are accommodated in the new generic R_Product RMIM.
The RMIMs are oriented around the following concepts:

a) Adverse experiences: Any adverse event associated with the use of a product in humans or animals, whether or not considered product related, including the following: An adverse event occurring in the course of the use of a product in professional practice; an adverse event occurring from overdose of the product whether accidental or intentional; an adverse event occurring from abuse of the product; an adverse event occurring from withdrawal of the product; and any failure of expected pharmacological action. Note these events may result in unintended harm to the patient by an act of commission or omission, rather than by the underlying disease or condition of the patient.

b) Suspected adverse reaction: A noxious and unintended response to a product for which there is a reasonable possibility that the product caused the response. In this definition, the phrase "a reasonable possibility" means that the relationship cannot be ruled out. The range of product types for which reports may be generated is set by regulatory and/or organizational administrative practice within the jurisdiction controlling the reporting between parties.

c) Suspected product problems or defects: Any problem or defect observed or detected before a product is used. This includes the use of drugs, biologics or medical devices used for treatment, or other consumer products such as cosmetics or dietary supplements. Some examples of product problems include faulty packaging or labeling, receipt of an expired therapeutic drug product, or suspected contamination based upon inappropriate or unauthorized preparations or mixtures.
d) An affected person or animal: If applicable to the report, this includes the investigative subject (patient) that experienced an adverse event.
e) Substance administrations: Includes information about how the product was given or used, or intended to be given or used by the investigative subject.

f) Medical procedures related to devices: Includes information about how a medical device was used or intended to be used by a patient or investigative subject. For example, device implant or removal procedures.

g) Supporting clinical information: Includes additional clinical detail such as relevant observations, procedures, substance administrations, supply acts or patient encounters. These observations are included if the reporter considers them relevant to the investigation, whether referring to the same point in time as the suspect event or as part of the patient's medical history.

The ICSR RMIM is designed to support within a single structure two aspects of product reporting. These include: 1) a report about the investigation into the adverse event(s) or reaction(s) suffered by an affected person or animal that experienced an intervention or interventions in a therapeutic context. The suspect event may or may not have a causal relationship with the administration or use of one or more products; and 2) a report about the investigation into a product problem. Note that the key common factor is the involvement of an implicated product such as a medication, device, dietary supplement or cosmetic.

This message, as with all HL7 V3 specifications, includes a Control Act structure which contains information about the actual report transmission. (The reader should refer to the HL7 V3 Infrastructure Management Domain for more details on this structure.)
Please refer to the HMD documentation for more detailed information on classes and attributes.

rmimref.refName: Public Health Reporting Domain Information Model
rmimref.refFamiliarName: Public Health Reporting Domain Information Model

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The A_DrugIntervention message element type captures relevant substance administration act information for cases in which use of a drug is associated with to a reported adverse reaction. The relevant information includes items related to the substance administration itself, to component parts of a more general administration act, as well as to ancillary information related to the substance administration. This message element type is being used to capture substance administrations for drugs, therapeutic biologics, and vaccines. In the ICSR Base model RMIM, this information is associated with the InvestigationEvent class through the ImplicatedAct association.

Note to implementers: This RMIM should only be used by implementers who are interested in drug adverse events and for whom compatibility with the HL7 Structured Product Labeling (SPL) model is of key importance. Otherwise, the committee recommends the use of the A_ProductUse RMIM.
Please refer to the HMD documentation for more detailed information on classes and attributes.

rmimref.refName: Public Health Reporting Domain Information Model
rmimref.refFamiliarName: Public Health Reporting Domain Information Model

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The A_DeviceIntervention message element type captures relevant medical device procedure information for medical device adverse event reporting. The intervention information includes items related to the procedure itself, to component parts of a more general procedure act, as well as to ancillary information related to the procedure.

Note to implementers: This model should only be used by early adopters of the ICSR Release 1 message specification, especially those organizations planning to submit electronic medical device reporting to the FDA's Center for Devices and Radiological Health (CDRH). It is recommended that implementers contact CDRH to obtain more information about medical device reporting. Otherwise, the committee recommends use of the A_ProductUse RMIM which can be used to capture the same information.
Please refer to the HMD documentation for more detailed information on classes and attributes.

rmimref.refName: Public Health Reporting Domain Information Model
rmimref.refFamiliarName: Public Health Reporting Domain Information Model

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The R_Drug message element type captures the drug product information that is relevant for related adverse event and product problem reporting. The term "drug" includes drugs, therapeutic biologics, and vaccines. Note that the R_Product message element type can also be used to capture drug product information. The relevant information includes items related to the drug itself and information about its manufacture and approval. The reader should note that this model has been modified to follow the pattern of the Structured Product Label (SPL) medication information model created by the Regulated Clinical Information Management Technical Committee the. The model was modified to minimize compatibility concerns for organizations which have already implemented SPL and intend to also use ICSR in the near future.
Please refer to the HMD documentation for more detailed information on classes and attributes.

rmimref.refName: Public Health Reporting Domain Information Model
rmimref.refFamiliarName: Public Health Reporting Domain Information Model

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The R_Device message element type captures specific medical device information that is relevant for device related adverse event and product problem reports. Note that early adopters of ICSR Release 1 should use this model and contact the FDA Center for Devices and Radiological Health (CDRH) to obtain more information about medical device reporting. The new ICSR Release 2 R_Product model can also be used for new implementations to capture device product information. The relevant information includes items related to the device itself, its manufacture, and evaluations performed by device manufacturers or reprocessors.

A device in this context refers to a manufactured product that is used directly in treating and/or caring for the patient. The model captures information about devices by using one central class - Device - to capture descriptive information directly related to the particular device, and another - DeviceModel to capture information about the specific type of device.
Please refer to the HMD documentation for more detailed information on classes and attributes.

rmimref.refName: Public Health Reporting Domain Information Model
rmimref.refFamiliarName: Public Health Reporting Domain Information Model

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The R_Product message element type captures product information relevant for a wide range of adverse event and product problem reporting requirements. This information includes items related to the product itself, its packaging, manufacture and potential post-event evaluation by manufacturers or reprocessors. Note that information about how a product was supplied (ordered) can be captured using the relevant Supply Act in the Supporting Clinical Statement CMET.
A product in this context refers to a manufactured or home fabricated item that is used directly by an investigative subject - whether person or animal. This model serves three purposes:

list.item: It provides a generic view of a product as opposed to the more specific product models for medicines (R_Drug) and medical devices (R_Device). This structure supports the FDA's (and presumably other reporting authorities') need for capturing product problems and adverse events associated with the use of other products such as foods, food additives, cosmetics, dietary supplements and veterinary drug products. The new structure provides all the attributes and functionality of the more specific product models.

It addresses the need for reporting related to combination products. This category includes products which combine drugs, biologics and/or medical devices into one product for therapeutic use. It also includes situations in which two or more separately licensed products are used together to achieve a specific purpose as documented in the relevant labeling information.

It provides a consolidated structure that can be used to replace the more specific product models for medicines and medical devices. This new structure supports migration for unification of the messaging specifications that support a wider variety of product types

descriptive.p: Please refer to the HMD documentation for more detailed information on classes and attributes.

rmimref.refName: Public Health Reporting Domain Information Model
rmimref.refFamiliarName: Public Health Reporting Domain Information Model

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The A_ProductUse message element type captures information about the acts that establish how a product was used by an investigative subject for product related adverse events and/or product problem (defect) reporting. The information includes items relevant to the use of the product and any associated clinical or other information directly related to the product's use. Note that this RMIM supports all attributes and functionality provided in the ICSR Release 1 A_DrugIntervention and A_DeviceIntervention models. ICSR Release 2 retained the use of these models to support a minimum level of backward compatibility between ICSR Release 1 and Release 2. However, for organizations that have not previously implemented ICSR Release 1, the committee recommends use of A_ProductUse, and caution implementers that the ICSR Release 1 intervention models may be deprecated over time in future releases of ICSR.

The ProductUse This choice structure captures information directly related to the use of the product that is relevant to the investigation. If it is necessary to introduce component usage, such as substance administrations or procedures, this initial usage will provide the overall context for the investigation.
Please refer to the HMD documentation for more detailed information on classes and attributes.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Device InterventionHMD includes the information related to medical device related procedures that are referred to in an ICSR. Note, this structure is essentially a PORR internal message element type.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Drug InterventionHMD includes the information related to drug related subtance administrations that are referred to in an ICSR. Note, this structure is essentially a PORR internal message element type.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This HMD includes the data that may be needed to file an ICSR report on an adverse event or reaction to a drug, biologic, vaccine, or device that has been implanted or is otherwise providing services to a patient. This also includes the data that may be needed to file an ICSR report on a drug or a device that has not been involved in a patient related reaction.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Device HMD includes the information related to medical devices that are referred to in an ICSR. Note, this structure is essentially a PORR internal message element type.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Drug HMD includes the information related to drugs that are referred to in an ICSR. Note, this structure is essentially a PORR internal message element type.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Drug InterventionHMD includes the information related to how a product was used by an investigated subject that are referred to in an ICSR. Note, this structure is essentially a PORR internal message element type.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The R_Product HMD includes the information related to product problem reporting that are referred to in an ICSR. Note, this structure is essentially a PORR internal message element type.
